Article.Abstract: The extracellular interferon gamma receptor alpha-chain comprises two immunoglobulin-like domains, each with fibronectin type-III topology, which are responsible for binding interferon gamma at the cell surface. The epitopes on the human receptor recognized by three neutralizing antibodies, A6, gammaR38 and gammaR99, have been mapped by homolog scanning mutagenesis. In this way, a loop connecting beta-strands C and C' in the N-terminal domain was identified as a key component of the epitopes bound by A6 and gammaR38, whereas gammaR99 binds to the C-terminal domain in a region including strands A and B and part of the large C'E loop. The epitope for A6 was confirmed in a crystal structure of a complex between a recombinant N-terminal receptor domain and the Fab fragment from A6, determined by X-ray diffraction to 2.8 A resolution. The antibody-antigen interface buries 1662 A2 of protein surface, including 22 antibody residues from five complementarity determining regions, primarily through interactions with the CC' surface loop of the receptor. The floor of the antigen binding cavity is formed mainly by residues from CDR L3 and CDR H3 while a surrounding ridge is formed by residues from all other CDRs except L2. Many potential polar interactions, as well as 13 aromatic side-chains, four in VL, six in VH and three in the receptor, are situated at the interface. The surface of the receptor contacted by A6 overlaps to a large extent with that contacted by interferon-gamma, in the ligand-receptor complex. However, the conformation of this epitope is very different in the two complexes, demonstrating that conformational mobility in a surface loop on this cytokine receptor permits steric and electrostatic complementarity to two quite differently shaped binding sites.
Article.ArticleTitle: Neutralizing epitopes on the extracellular interferon gamma receptor (IFNgammaR) alpha-chain characterized by homolog scanning mutagenesis and X-ray crystal structure of the A6 fab-IFNgammaR1-108 complex.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Zurich, Winterthurerstrasse 190, Zurich, 8057, Switzerland.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, CD;Immunoglobulin Fab Fragments;Macromolecular Substances;Receptors, Interferon;interferon gamma receptor;Interferon-gamma
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Antigen-Antibody Reactions; Antigens, CD(immunology); Biosensing Techniques; Computer Simulation; Crystallography, X-Ray; Epitope Mapping; Humans; Immunoglobulin Fab Fragments; Interferon-gamma(immunology); Macromolecular Substances; Models, Molecular; Molecular Sequence Data; Mutagenesis, Site-Directed; Protein Conformation; Receptors, Interferon(immunology)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Generation of the monoclonal antibody A6 was previously described in the reference cited: Aguet and Merlin (1987) J Exp Med 165: 988-999 [PMID: 2435837]. Generation of the monoclonal antibody γR38 was previously described in the reference cited: Garotta et al. (1990) J Biol Chem 265: 6908-6915 [PMID: 1691178].

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Residues critical for binding epitope-specific mAb A6 were determined by binding to mutants of IFN-γR (residues 1-229; corresponding to residues 18-246 in GenBank entry). The apparent dissociation constant is reduced 400-fold (KD = 5820 nM) when the epitopic region (CC' loop; N48V, Δ(G50V51K52), N53S, S54G, E55S, I57T), determined in crystallographic studies, is mutated. Other mutations do not affect the interaction, with the exception of mutations in region 71-81 (S71Y, D72E, H73Q, V74I, G75M, D76Y, S78D, N79V, L81A; residues 88-98 in GenBank entry) that forms the EF loop, induce a 148-fold reduction of the affinity (KD = 2100 nM) and may exert an influence on the conformation of the epitopic CC' loop. Similar results are obtained with mAb γR38 (KD = 32.9 nM), which is supposed to recognize a related, but not identical, epitope.

BCell.LocationOfData: Tables 2, 3, 4 and Figures 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 and PDB 1 JRH

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Generation of the monoclonal antibody A6 was previously described in the reference cited: Aguet and Merlin (1987) J Exp Med 165: 988-999 [PMID: 2435837].

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope recognized by neutralizing mAb A6 was determined by x-ray crystallographic analysis of the complex between Fab A6 and arecombinant N-terminal D1 domain of the IFNγR (residues 1-108 with a Cys105Ser point mutation). This epitope is part of the CC' loop of the molecule, involved in IFN-g binding. The numbering in this study starts at position 18 of the GenBank entry sequence. IFNgR1 encodes the ligand-binding chain (alpha) of the heterodimeric gamma interferon receptor.

Antigen.AntigenReferenceName: IFNγRα-chain, N-terminal D1 domain 1-108, mutation C105S

Epitope.EpitopeName: mAb γR99 epitope on IFNγR α-chain

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Generation of the monoclonal antibody γR99 was previously described in the reference cited: Garotta et al. (1990) J Biol Chem 265: 6908-6915 [PMID: 1691178]. Mice were immunized with a preparation of human IFNγ-R that was 20-50% pure.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Residues critical for binding epitope-specific mAb γR99 were determined by binding to mutants of IFN-γR (residues 1-229; corresponding to residues 18-246 in GenBank entry). The apparent dissociation constant is reduced from 48 to 874-fold when the residues implicated in this epitopic region are mutated. The most severe reduction of binding was observed with mutant D116E, I117R, E120K (KD = 2360 nM), followed by mutant Q173V, K174E, E175K, D176E, D177E, D179N, I181T, Q182L, Q184E (KD = 673 nM) and mutant K122E, I124L, M125S, I126V, D127L, I128V (KD = 130 nM). Other mutations do not affect the interaction, suggesting that the epitope is contained within that region. This epitopic region is located in the face to the receptor defined by strands A and B and part of the C'E loop, in the C-terminal part of the IgG-like domain. This region is not involved in IFN-gamma binding, as seen in crystallographic studies, so the mechanism of action of this neutralizing mAb is unclear.
